q:
Bob is working on Java Server Pages and he wants to safely display user-provided data to a page. Which of the following JSTL tags can Bob use to do this task?



 

  1. <c:out>

     
  2. <c:safe>

     
  3. <c:encode>
In JSP, which of the following methods is used to set a response header with the desired name and the date?
In JSP, which of the following methods returns the current session that is associated with a request?

What is the XML equivalent of the following JSP code:

      <%@ include file="relative url" >
Which of these methods is used by the JSP to submit itself to the garbage collection?

Which of the following statements for JSP language is true:

  1. JSP Expression: <%=Java Value%>
  2. JSP Scriplet      :<%Java Statement%>
  3. JSP Declaration: <%! Field/method Defination%>

Which of these options best describes the following JSP code:

<taglib>
<tlib-version>1.0</tlib-version>
<jsp-version>2.0</jsp-version>
<short-name>.....</short-name>
<tag>
<name>...</name>
<tag-class>....</tag-class>
<body-content>...</body-content>
</tag>
</taglib>
.....

<%@ taglib prefix="myprefix" uri="WEB-INF/message.tld"%>
<html>
......
<body>
  <myprefix:MyMsg>
   JSP Program!
  </myprefix:MyMsg>
</body>
</html>

a.option: Use of custom tags in the  JSP architecture

q:
What is the output of the following JSP code:

public class MyBean {
  
  private String name=new String();
  
  public String getName() {
  return name;
  }
  public void setName(String name) {
  this.name = name;
  }
  } 
......
<html>
.....
<body>
<jsp:useBean id="mybean" class="MyBean" scope="session" >
<jsp:setProperty name="mybean" property="name" value="JSP Program!" />
</jsp:useBean>

<b> <jsp:getProperty name="mybean" property="name" /></b>
</body>
</html>

......

boolean sessionDebug = false;

Properties props = .....;

props.put("mail.host", host);
props.put("mail.transport.protocol", "smtp");

Which of the following statements about JSP are true:

  1. JSP can easily be integrated with JavaBeans.
  2. JSP is much used in frameworks such as Sturts.
  3. JSP needs no compilation by the programmer. Programmer deploys a JSP source code file in server directly.
  4. With JSP, the programmer can build custom tags that can be called in JavaBeans directly.
  5. Writing alias name in <url-pattern> tag of web.xml is optional in JSP.

What will be displayed when the following JSP code is executed:

...
<%@ page language="java" contentType="text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1"
 pageEncoding="ISO-8859-1"%>
.....
<meta http-equiv="Content-Type" content="text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1">
<body>
 <jsp:forward page="/welcome.jsp">
  <jsp:param name="firstName" value="Enter First Name" />
  <jsp:param name="lastName" value="Enter Last Name" />
 </jsp:forward>
 <h1>Hello this is the index page!</h1>
</body>
</html>

a.option: A page can never be forwarded in JSP.
The welcome.jsp page will be displayed.

q:
What is the output of the following JSP code:

<html>
.....
.......
<body>
<%
try{
int i = 1;
i = i / 0;
out.println("The answer is " + i);
}
catch (Exception e){
out.println("An exception occurred: " + e.getMessage());
}
%>
</body>
</html>

Which of these options will you use to complete the line A in the following JSP code:

<%@page import="javax.servlet.http.Cookie"%>
<html>
   <body>
        <%
            Cookie cookie = new Cookie("ClientID","JSP_Program");
             cookie.setMaxAge(60*60);
            ( _____________________) /**Line A**/
        %>
    </body>
</html>

Which of the following is an implicit object in JSP:

  1. session
  2. pageContext
  3. application
  4. page
  5. config

Which of these options will you use to complete the line A in the following JSP code:

<%@ page import = "java.io.*,java.util.*" %>
<html>
 <body>
  <h2>Header Request Example</h2>
  ..........
.........     
    <%
        Enumeration headerNames = request.getHeaderNames();
        while(headerNames.hasMoreElements()) {
          String paramName = (String)headerNames.nextElement();
           ..........
          String paramValue = (......); /**Line A**/
         out.println("<td> " + paramValue + "</td></tr>\n");
               }
     %>

What is the error in the following JSP code:

<%@ page import="java.io.*,java.util.*" %>
<html>
   .....
    <body>
        <form>
     <fieldset style="width:20%; background-color:#e6ffe6;">
       
      <%
           Integer hits = /**Line A**/
              (Integer)application.getAttribute("hitCounter");
               if( hits ==null || hits == 0 )
               {                  
                  out.println("Welcome to my website!!");
                  hits = 1;
                    }
               else
                    {                       
                        out.println("Welcome to my website!!");
                        hits += 1;
                    }
                    application.setAttribute("hitCounter", hits); /**Line B**/
            %>
         <p>You are visitor number: <%= hits%></p>

a.option: The value of hits is always one.
The value of hits increases when a page request is made.

q:
What is the error in the following JSP code:

                     <%
                        response.setIntHeader(".....", 1);
                           ......
                         Calendar calendar = new GregorianCalendar();
                       .......
                       int hr = calendar.get(Calendar.HOUR);
                       int min = calendar.get(Calendar.MINUTE);
                       int sec= calendar.get(Calendar.SECOND);
                       ......
                         ......
                String CT = hr+":"+ min +":"+ sec;
                out.println("Current Time: " + CT + "\n");
                    %>

a.option: No error but the page is never refreshed
No error and the page refreshes at an interval of one second
